questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and early satiety for the past three months. His clothes are looser than usual. Past medical history is significant for hypertension managed with lisinopril. Family history is noncontributory. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history, drinks alcohol occasionally, and does not use other recreational drugs. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows a thin, pale, and cachexic man. Abdominal examination is significant for an enlarged spleen on palpation. CT scan abdomen shows an irregular mass arising posteriorly from the greater curvature of the stomach and compressing the splenic vessels. If the mass continues to enlarge, tissue supplied by which of the following vessels is most likely to be compromised in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation suggests a gastric tumor compressing the splenic vessels posteriorly. The splenic artery originates from the celiac artery and courses superiorly to the pancreas, giving off branches to the stomach and pancreas before reaching the spleen. These branches include: 
  •  Greater pancreatic artery and dorsal pancreatic artery 
  •  Short gastric arteries 
  •  Left gastroepiploic artery 
  •  Posterior gastric artery 
The short gastric arteries supply the fundus of the stomach along the proximal greater curvature where they have very poor anastomoses if the splenic artery is blocked. Therefore, this area is vulnerable to ischemia in the case of splenic artery blockage. In contrast, the left gastroepiploic artery which supplies the body of the stomach at the greater curvature forms strong anastomoses with the right gastroepiploic artery, and this region is usually spared from ischemia if the splenic artery is blocked.  



Option Analysis

✅ Short gastric arteries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left gastric artery:
Incorrect: The left gastric artery arises from the celiac artery and runs along the superior portion of the lesser curvature of the stomach. It anastomoses with the right gastric artery, which runs right to left. Splenic vessel compression would not involve the lesser curvature.  
❌ Gastroduodenal artery:
Incorrect:  Gastroduodenal arteries (branch of the common hepatic artery) supply the pylorus of the stomach and the duodenal bulb. This region would not be affected by splenic artery obstruction.  
❌ Proper hepatic artery:
Incorrect: Proper hepatic artery is a branch of the common hepatic artery, which supplies blood to the liver and gallbladder. Splenic artery obstruction would not affect these structures.  
❌ Left gastroepiploic artery:
Incorrect: The left gastroepiploic artery is a branch of the splenic artery that supplies blood to the body of the stomach along the greater curvature. It forms an anastomosis with the right gastroepiploic artery (branch of the gastroduodenal artery). Therefore, this region of the stomach would not be at risk for ischemia with splenic artery blockage.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man was brought to the emergency department with sudden onset severe abdominal pain and vomiting that began 6 hours ago. He reports intermittent crampy abdominal pain and bloating over the past week. However, since the early morning, the pain has been severe and sharp in nature and associated with nausea. He has been receiving chemotherapy for a known diagnosis of colorectal cancer. Additional past medical history is significant for hypertension, controlled with lisinopril. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals absent bowel sounds and generalized abdominal tenderness, distension, and involuntary guarding over the lower abdomen. IV fluids are initiated. An upright chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 

 Reproduced from: Openi

choices.text: Broad-spectrum antibiotics and urgent surgical consultation
CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Nasogastric tube placement, bowel rest, and serial monitoring

questions.solution:
The patient's clinical presentation of severe abdominal pain, distension, nausea, tenderness, guarding, and absent bowel sounds, in the setting of known colorectal cancer, is concerning for bowel obstruction. The sudden onset of severe symptoms combined with involuntary guarding on physical examination and presence of pneumoperitoneum (i.e. air under the diaphragm) observed on upright chest x-ray, indicates bowel perforation, which is a life-threatening complication requiring broad-spectrum antibiotics and urgent surgical consultation.

In patients with colorectal cancer, the bowel wall can become compromised due to the pressure from tumor growth, which increases the risk of necrosis and perforation. When this occurs, bowel contents seep into the peritoneal cavity, resulting in bacterial peritonitis, requiring immediate intervention. Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics is crucial, ensuring that both gram-positive and gram-negative pathogens are targeted. Concurrently, emergent surgical consultation is necessary. Typically, an exploratory laparotomy is performed to repair or resect the perforated segment.  

Option Analysis

✅ Broad-spectrum antibiotics and urgent surgical consultation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Colonoscopy is a diagnostic tool for colorectal neoplasms and lower gastrointestinal bleeding. It is contraindicated in the setting of suspected bowel perforation due to the risk of exacerbating the perforation.  
❌ CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: While a CT scan would delineate the extent and source of the perforation and the likely obstruction, the urgency of this patient's condition (bowel perforation with pneumoperitoneum) necessitates immediate surgical intervention.  
❌ Nasogastric tube placement, bowel rest, and serial monitoring:
Incorrect: Nasogastric decompression and bowel rest can be the initial steps in treatment of uncomplicated bowel obstruction, but the presence of pneumoperitoneum and associated signs of peritonitis (guarding) demands a more aggressive surgical approach.  
❌ Colonic stent placement:
Incorrect: Colonic stent placement might be utilized for palliative treatment in patients with obstructing colorectal cancer. In the case of a suspected bowel perforation and resulting peritonitis, urgent surgical intervention is necessary.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with rectal bleeding, anal pain, and discomfort during bowel movements for the past three weeks. She has not had any significant weight loss, changes in bowel habits, or abdominal pain. She has smoked 1-pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. She has a history of high-risk HPV and prior cervical changes detected on a PAP smear. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a 1.5 cm ulcerated perianal lesion. Biopsy of the mass reveals a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, and imaging confirms stage I disease that does not involve the sphincter. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Wide surgical excision of the mass

questions.solution:
This patient with well-differentiated stage I squamous cell perianal cancer should be referred for wide surgical excision of the mass.  Due to the small size, perianal location of the tumor, and well-differentiated cell features, the likelihood of cure with surgery alone is high. If the surgical margins are positive for disease, re-excision or treatment with chemotherapy will be needed.

The first step in determining whether squamous cell anal cancer should be managed with chemoradiation versus surgery is to establish the location of the tumor. Cancers within the anal canal are managed with chemoradiation. If the tumor is located in the perianal region, as in this patient, the next step is to stage the tumor and evaluate how well the cells are differentiated to determine whether chemoradiation or surgery is indicated. For stage 1 perianal lesions that are 2 cm or smaller in size that are well or moderately differentiated, wide local excision is recommended. Surgical management can also be considered for patients with stage 2A disease (i.e. tumor greater than 2 cm but less than or equal to 5 cm) that does not involve the sphincter. More advanced cancers should be treated with chemoradiation. Systemic chemotherapy can be used to treat metastatic disease. Adenocarcinomas are treated differently based on the TNM staging.  

Option Analysis

❌ Chemoradiation:
Incorrect: This patient has a small well-differentiated stage 1 perianal cancer. For perianal SCC, stage 1 tumors that are well or moderately differentiated, or stage 2A tumors not involving the sphincter, treatment is surgical resection.  
❌ Palliative care:
Incorrect: Palliative care is indicated for patients with advanced, incurable disease to provide comfort and manage symptoms This patient has a well-differentiated, stage 1 disease that does not involve the sphincter and can likely be cured with surgical excision.  
✅ Wide surgical excision of the mass:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Immunotherapy and chemotherapy:
Incorrect: This patient has a small well-differentiated stage 1 perianal cancer. For perianal SCC, stage 1 tumors that are well or moderately differentiated, or stage 2A tumors not involving the sphincter, treatment is surgical resection.  
❌ Surveillance with regular imaging studies:
Incorrect: For localized, resectable stage 1 perianal cancer, the standard of care is surgical excision. Surveillance without surgery can lead to disease progression, invasion of nearby structures, and potential complications. Early intervention with surgical excision offers the best chance of cure.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to the office to discuss next steps after a recent diagnosis of gastric cancer. She recently presented to the emergency department with refractory dyspepsia and weight loss and underwent an upper endoscopy with biopsies. The endoscopy was notable for a fungating mass in the gastric antrum, and biopsies showed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. Endoscopic ultrasound was performed and showed invasion into the muscularis propria and no suspicious lymph nodes. She was prescribed treatment for H. Pylori. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis with oral and IV contrast

questions.solution:
After a tissue diagnosis of gastric cancer has been made, additional workup is necessary to complete TNM staging of the tumor. The T stage of gastric cancer correlates with the depth of tumor penetration into the layers of the gastric wall (see table below). Generally, depth of tumor penetration is determined via endoscopic ultrasound. This patient underwent endoscopic ultrasound during an upper endoscopy for presumed gastric cancer. Her lesion extends into the muscularis propria, making it a T2 lesion. Surrounding lymph nodes are also assessed on endoscopic ultrasound - when suspicious, they are biopsied via FNA. However, no suspicious nodes were noted in this patient. The most appropriate next step is to complete a metastatic workup with computed tomography of the chest, abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast.

CT is widely available, noninvasive, and is well suited for evaluating widely metastatic disease, especially hepatic or adnexal metastases, ascites, and distant nodal spread. Patients who have CT-defined visceral metastatic disease can avoid unnecessary surgery, although biopsy confirmation is recommended because of the risk of false-positive findings.

The goal of the initial staging evaluation is to stratify patients into two clinical groups in order to guide initial management: those with locoregional, potentially resectable (stage I to III) disease and those with either locally advanced, unresectable or metastatic (stage IV) disease. The most common sites for metastasis are the liver, peritoneum or distant lymph nodes. Once staging is complete, the patient can be referred to obtain the appropriate treatment.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Chemotherapy:
Incorrect: While this patient most likely will require treatment with chemotherapy, appropriate staging with a metastatic workup is needed prior to initiating treatment.  
❌ Obtain CEA, CA 19-9 and CA 125:
Incorrect: Serum tumor markers are included in the workup for several cancers, including colon cancer (CEA), pancreatic cancer (CA 19-9) and ovarian cancer (CA 125). However, they are not included in the staging workup of gastric cancer. There are currently no tumor markers used commonly to evaluate disease burden in gastric cancer.  
✅ CT Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis with oral and IV contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ FDG-PET Scan:
Incorrect: PET-CT is reserved for those patients who have equivocal findings on CT imaging or patients with clinical indications of possible metastatic disease and otherwise negative imaging. This patient still requires initial imaging with CT Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis with oral and IV contrast for staging.  
❌ Diagnostic laparoscopy:
Incorrect: Staging laparoscopy is used to detect occult peritoneal dissemination in patients with more than a T1a lesion on EUS, and no histologic confirmation of stage IV disease, who would not otherwise require palliative gastrectomy because of symptoms. Diagnostic laparoscopy should also be undertaken in any patient who is being considered for neoadjuvant therapy. This patient first needs staging with CT Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis with oral and IV contrast.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of progressive difficulty swallowing, initially with solid foods but now also with liquids. She describes a sensation of food 'sticking' in her throat and pain with swallowing. She has also experienced occasional regurgitation of undigested food, unintentional weight loss (baseline BMI of 20.7), and a persistent dry cough, especially at night. She has a history of H. pylori infection that was treated one year ago and resolved. She has a 30-pack year smoking history and currently smokes a pack a day. She drinks one alcoholic drink every few months when she meets up with friends. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate is 76/min, blood pressure is 132/78 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 14/min. BMI is 19. Oral examination is unremarkable. Neck examination shows no lymphadenopathy. Abdominal examination is significant for mild epigastric tenderness. Endoscopy reveals an esophageal lesion. Which of the following most likely contributed to the development of this patient’s underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with progressive difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) first to solids and then to liquids, regurgitation of undigested food, pain with swallowing (odynophagia), significant weight loss, and a persistent dry cough and is found to have an esophageal lesion on EGD. This patient likely has esophageal cancer and smoking likely contributed to the development of esophageal cancer in this patient.    

Many patients with esophageal cancer are asymptomatic or symptoms are subtle. Patients may present with iron deficiency anemia due to blood loss. Patients with advanced disease may present with progressive dysphagia (initially to solids, then to liquids), odynophagia (painful swallowing), unexplained weight loss, and possibly regurgitation of undigested food. Patients may also have persistent cough or hoarseness, reflecting the tumor's impact on adjacent structures.      

Smoking and chronic alcohol use are significant risk factors for esophageal cancer, and they act synergistically, particularly for squamous cell carcinoma. Chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is another risk factor. It can lead to Barrett esophagus, predisposing individuals to adenocarcinoma of the esophagus. Dietary factors, such as consumption of very hot beverages, poor intake of fresh fruits and vegetables, and intake of preserved foods, can also contribute. Additionally, a history of head and neck cancers, exposure to certain chemicals (like lye), and genetic predispositions can increase the risk as well.  

Option Analysis

✅ Smoking :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Alcohol consumption:
Incorrect: This patient with dysphagia, odynophagia, unintentional weight loss, and persistent cough likely has esophageal cancer. While chronic alcohol consumption is a risk factor for esophageal cancer, it is usually in the context of heavy, long-term use. Her occasional alcoholic drink has not likely contributed to the development of esophageal cancer.
❌ BMI at baseline:
Incorrect: This patient had a normal BMI at baseline. A high BMI is associated with the development of esophageal cancer.
❌ Female sex:
Incorrect: This patient likely has esophageal cancer. Esophageal cancer, especially squamous cell carcinoma, is more common in men than women. 
❌ Helicobacter pylori infection:
Incorrect: This patient likely has esophageal cancer. Although Helicobacter pylori infection is associated with gastric cancer, its role in esophageal cancer is less clear. Studies have shown that it is protective for esophageal adenocarcinoma. The patient's smoking history is a more direct and significant risk factor for esophageal cancer, particularly squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of difficulty swallowing that began with solids and has progressed to liquids over the past three months. Additionally, he reports a recent onset of voice hoarseness and chest pain when eating. He has unintentionally lost 10 kg (22 lbs) during the past three months. He has no significant past medical history. He has a 40-pack year smoking history and consumes 3 drinks of alcohol approximately 5 nights a week. BMI is 21 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate is 88/min, blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. He appears pale and thin. There is no palpable lymphadenopathy in the neck. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Which of the following tests should be ordered next to help make a diagnosis?

choices.text: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the chest and abdomen

questions.solution:
This patient presents with progressive dysphagia, unintentional weight loss, voice hoarseness, and a history of smoking and excessive alcohol use. Progressive dysphagia, progressing from dysphagia with solids to dysphagia with liquids can be seen in esophageal cancer as the lumen narrows due to a growing tumor.  When esophageal cancer is suspected, esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) with biopsies should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.    

EGD with biopsy, allows for direct visualization of the esophagus, assessment of tumor extent, and tissue sampling for histological evaluation. Histopathology will differentiate between the two main types of esophageal cancer: adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma. Adenocarcinoma, often located in the distal esophagus, is commonly associated with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and Barrett esophagus. In contrast, squamous cell carcinoma typically arises in the upper and middle esophagus and is strongly linked to smoking and alcohol use.    

Following diagnosis, staging should be done with contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scans of the chest and abdomen (+/- pelvis) to assess for local invasion and distant metastases. Endoscopic ultrasound is used to evaluate tumor depth and nearby lymph node involvement, and a PET scan may be performed to assess for metastatic disease. Accurate staging is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment, which may vary significantly based on the stage and histological subtype.  

Option Analysis

✅ Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) with biopsies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Barium swallow study:
Incorrect: This patient is suspected of having esophageal cancer. A barium swallow can delineate structural abnormalities of the esophagus but lacks specificity and is not able to provide a histological diagnosis. It may be useful in the initial evaluation of dysphagia but is not the best next step in suspected esophageal cancer.
❌ Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the chest and abdomen:
Incorrect: While a CT scan of the chest and abdomen is part of the staging for esophageal cancer, particularly for assessing metastasis, it does not provide a definitive diagnosis or histological classification. 
❌ Esophageal manometry:
Incorrect: Esophageal manometry is used for diagnosing motility disorders, which typically cause dysphagia in both solids and liquids from the start, unlike this patient’s progressive dysphagia. Given his clinical presentation and risk factors, esophageal cancer is more likely, and should be diagnosed with EGD with biopsies.
❌ 24-hour pH monitoring:
Incorrect: This test evaluates for gastroesophageal reflux disease, which can be a precursor to adenocarcinoma, but it cannot make a histological diagnosis of esophageal cancer. This patient’s symptoms suggest esophageal cancer and EGD with biopsies is necessary for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic for a follow-up after a motor vehicle collision that occurred one week ago and resulted in a fractured left wrist without other injuries. As part of the trauma evaluation, a computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis was done and revealed a hepatic lesion in segment 4 of the liver. The patient’s only past medical history is hypertension, which is well controlled with amlodipine. He does not have abdominal pain, jaundice, or recent weight loss. Physical exam is within normal limits. Which of the following findings on initial imaging would prompt further diagnostic workup with multiphase contrast CT of the abdomen/pelvis?

choices.text: Lesion that is 6 cm with irregular margins
Small lesions showing no growth when compared to prior CT done one year ago
Lesion < 1 cm with smooth borders and multiple subcentimeter gallstones in the gallbladder

questions.solution:
This patient is asymptomatic with an incidental hepatic lesion found on abdominal CT with contrast. In asymptomatic patients without risk factors for malignant hepatic lesions, characteristics of the lesion on CT can be used to determine if further diagnostic evaluation is necessary. Features indicating the need for further diagnostic imaging include lesion size ≥ 1 cm, irregular borders/margins, and findings on initial CT that are consistent with malignancy or with benign lesions that would require treatment. Contrast-enhanced, multiphase imaging of the abdomen/pelvis with either CT or MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) should be ordered when further workup is required. A lesion that is 6 cm in size with irregular margins is suspicious for malignancy and warrants further diagnostic evaluation.

Hepatic lesions can be solid or cystic, and arise from benign, malignant, or infectious etiologies. Most patients with an incidental hepatic mass are asymptomatic, but patients with symptomatic lesions can present with fever, chills, and right upper quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain. Physical examination may reveal abdominal distension, RUQ tenderness, a palpable liver edge (i.e., hepatomegaly), or scleral icterus and jaundice.

Patients with incidental hepatic lesions who have cirrhosis or risk factors for cirrhosis (e.g. alcoholism, chronic hepatitis B) should have further diagnostic workup regardless of the characteristics of the lesion on the initial CT. Additionally, patients with alarm features (e.g., weight loss, RUQ pain, prior malignancy that can metastasize to the liver) should have further imaging with multiphase contrast-enhanced imaging regardless of the initial CT findings.
 
    

Option Analysis

❌ Lesion < 1 cm with smooth margins  :
Incorrect: Typically, lesions < 1 cm in size with smooth margins are benign and can be followed yearly with history, physical, and imaging. These lesions do not require immediate diagnostic workup.  
❌ Lesion < 3 cm that is well-demarcated, homogenous, and hyperechoic  :
Incorrect: In patients with these CT findings and no history of cirrhosis or malignancy, hepatic hemangioma can typically be diagnosed without the need for further diagnostic imaging.  
✅ Lesion that is 6 cm with irregular margins  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Small lesions showing no growth when compared to prior CT done one year ago :
Incorrect: Hepatic lesions that are stable or regress on subsequent CT are benign and do not require further workup.  
❌ Lesion < 1 cm with smooth borders and multiple subcentimeter gallstones in the gallbladder :
Incorrect: While this patient should be offered a surgery consultation for elective cholecystectomy. This lesion that is <1 cm with smooth borders is most likely benign and does not require further diagnostic workup at this time.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of right upper quadrant abdominal discomfort, nausea, and vomiting. The patient reports subjective fevers and yellowing of her eyes. She has a past medical history of hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and arthritis for which she takes Naproxen daily. The patient had a laparoscopic cholecystectomy performed two years ago. She drinks 2-3 mixed drinks daily. She recently traveled to New Orleans where she had several seafood dinners. Temperature is 38.6°C (102.4°F), blood pressure is 144/66 mmHg, pulse is 97/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination there is scleral icterus and jaundice, right upper quadrant tenderness, and hepatomegaly. The patient does not have evidence of ascites or stigmata of cirrhosis. Initial laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following tests will be most helpful for making the diagnosis?
 
Laboratory value

Complete Blood Count (CBC)  

Hemoglobin
13 g/dL  
White blood cell count (WBC)  
9,000/mm3

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, associated fevers, and vomiting. Her laboratory findings are consistent with a hepatic pattern of injury. Given her history of laparoscopic cholecystectomy and lack of cholestatic pattern of injury on bloodwork, a biliary process is not likely. Her history of eating seafood, signs and symptoms, physical exam findings, and laboratory results are all consistent with viral hepatitis (either hepatitis A or E, likely from uncooked shellfish). Serologic testing for viral hepatitis should be ordered next to confirm the likely diagnosis.

The workup for stable patients with upper abdominal pain begins with obtaining basic blood work. Patients with right upper quadrant or epigastric pain should have a CBC, CMP, lipase, and amylase ordered. Patients with left upper quadrant pain typically require only a CBC and CMP. The results of these studies will often aid in determining the differential diagnosis and further workup. Right upper quadrant pain with a hepatic pattern of injury suggests acute viral hepatitis, toxin-related hepatitis (eg. acetaminophen), alcoholic hepatitis, or nonalcoholic steatohepatitis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Serologic testing for viral hepatitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Serum antimitochondrial antibodies:
Incorrect: Serum antimitochondrial antibodies are seen in patients with primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC), which typically presents with a cholestatic pattern of injury on bloodwork and not a hepatic pattern as seen in this case. Patients usually are asymptomatic or have associated pruritus.  
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP):
Incorrect: ERCP is the initial test for patients presenting with acute cholangitis since it can be used for both diagnosis and treatment with biliary decompression. This patient’s blood work shows a hepatic pattern of injury and not a cholestatic pattern that would be seen with acute cholangitis.  
❌ Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan:
Incorrect: Cholescintigraphy using 99mTc-HIDA scan is indicated in patients with suspected cholecystitis not evident on ultrasound. This patient has had a laparoscopic cholecystectomy.  
❌ Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP):
Incorrect: MRCP is typically obtained for nonurgent evaluation of suspected choledocholitihiasis that is not evident on ultrasound. This patient's clinical presentation is more consistent with hepatitis given the hepatic pattern of injury.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of bright red blood per rectum over the past 4 hours, not associated with pain. The patient reports feeling light-headed, prompting him to come to the emergency department. Medical history is significant for a history of hypertension and constipation. He had a colonoscopy 2 years ago at the age of 65 which showed diverticula and benign polyps which were removed. He had one prior episode of bright red blood per rectum in the past which stopped on its own. Temperature is 98.9°F; blood pressure is 82/48 mmHg; pulse is 122/minute; respiratory rate is 18/minute, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, he is awake, but lethargic. There is no tenderness to palpation of the abdomen. Rectal exam shows bright red blood, no visible hemorrhoids, and no tenderness on palpation of the anus. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Transfusion of packed red blood cells

questions.solution:
This patient presents with an acute episode of hematochezia and low blood pressure likely with active gastrointestinal bleeding. Hematochezia (bright red blood per rectum) is usually secondary to lower gastrointestinal bleeding that originates from a site distal to the ligament of Treitz, however a large brisk upper GI bleed can also cause hematochezia and instability. All patients presenting with hematochezia should be assessed for stability. Obtaining IV access immediately and starting fluid resuscitation is important in this patient who is presenting with hypotension and tachycardia. This patient is unstable and requires stabilization of heart rate and blood pressure before proceeding with imaging or procedures.

Blood tests should be ordered to assess the patient’s hemoglobin and need for transfusion while he is being stabilized. If the hemoglobin is less than 7 g/dl, the patient should receive blood transfusions. A higher threshold for transfusion (hemoglobin less than 9 g/dl) should be considered in patients with massive bleeding, significant comorbid illness (including cardiac ischemia), or if there will be a delay in receiving therapeutic interventions.

Once he is stabilized, this patient can have an upper GI endoscopy to rule out an upper GI source of bleeding. If upper endoscopy is negative, then a lower GI bleed would be suspected, and a colonoscopy should be done within the first 24 hours of presentation to the hospital for diagnosis and potential treatment.  

Option Analysis

✅ IV fluid resuscitation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy:
Incorrect: Hematochezia with hemodynamic instability could be a sign of a brisk upper GI bleed, which requires a workup with an upper endoscopy. This should be done after the patient has been stabilized.  
❌ Transfusion of packed red blood cells:
Incorrect: The patient is actively bleeding as noted by the bright red blood per rectum and low blood pressure. He may need a transfusion; however, IV access should be established immediately so that resuscitation with IV fluids can begin while blood tests are being obtained.  
❌ CT scan of the abdomen:
Incorrect: CT scan of the abdomen may be helpful for identifying acute pathology leading to the bleed. The patient is currently hemodynamically unstable and should be resuscitated with IV fluids before any imaging is done.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: A colonoscopy is important in the workup of hematochezia to visualize the possible source of bleeding. After the patient has been stabilized hemodynamically, a colonoscopy may be considered for further evaluation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by EMS after a syncopal episode at home. She has been experiencing bright red blood per rectum for the past 24 hours. Temperature is 99.4°F, blood pressure is 80/48 mmHg, pulse is 130/minute, respiratory rate is 22/minute, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. While in transport, 2 large bore IVs were placed and she was given 1-liter normal saline bolus. On arrival at the emergency department, her blood pressure is 95/50 mmHg and heart rate is 120/minute. She is given another liter of normal saline. She has a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. She has not had any previous colonoscopies. Physical examination reveals a pale woman who appears ill. She does not have abdominal tenderness to palpation. Rectal examination reveals bright red blood in the rectal vault. Hemoglobin is 8.5. Her blood pressure responds well to IV fluid resuscitation. Which of the following diagnostic studies should be performed next?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with hematochezia with hemodynamic instability. She has already begun to receive fluid resuscitation with improvements in her blood pressure. After stabilization, a focused history and physical examination should be performed, and initial laboratory tests should be sent. Upper endoscopy should then be performed since the source of her GI bleeding is unclear and large brisk upper GI bleeds can cause hematochezia and hemodynamic instability. If the upper endoscopy fails to reveal a source of bleeding, a colonoscopy should then be performed.

A Colonoscopy has been shown to identify the source of lower GI bleeds in more than 75% of patients. A colonoscopy should be done within 24 hours of admission, following adequate bowel prep, if a lower GI bleed is suspected. If the patient is not stable enough for a colonoscopy or has ongoing massive bleeding, other forms of evaluation should be considered such as CT angiography and tagged red blood cell scan.

Option Analysis

✅ Capsule endoscopy:
Correct: Capsule endoscopy can be used to evaluate the small intestine if upper endoscopy and colonoscopy fail to reveal the source of GI bleeding.  
❌ CT angiography:
Incorrect: CT angiography is a diagnostic modality that can be used for localizing the bleeding site. In this patient, an upper GI source of bleeding, that may be diagnosed and treated with upper endoscopy, should first be ruled out.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: A colonoscopy is the diagnostic test of choice in all patients presenting with an acute lower GI bleed. In patients, like this one, with an unclear source of bleeding, upper endoscopy should be performed first, and then if it is negative, colonoscopy can be performed.  
❌ Tagged red blood cell scan:
Incorrect: A tagged red blood cell scan can sometimes be used to help localize the site of bleeding if other modalities have not found the source.  
❌ CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: CT of the abdomen and pelvis can further evaluate for abdominal pathology or complications, but upper endoscopy and colonoscopy should be performed first to locate the source of bleeding.

This patient with a history of alcohol use disorder and chronic NSAID use presents for evaluation of epigastric abdominal pain. The patient has a positive stool hemoccult test and evidence of anemia on his screening CBC, suggestive of a bleeding peptic ulcer. Gastroenterology should be consulted for upper endoscopy for diagnosis and potential treatment.

Classifying upper abdominal pain by location can help with making the differential diagnosis for upper abdominal pain. Right upper quadrant pain may be caused by biliary or hepatic processes including acute cholecystitis, biliary colic, choledocholithiasis, acute cholangitis, acute hepatitis, liver abscess, Budd-Chiari syndrome, and portal vein thrombosis. Epigastric pain can be caused by pancreatic or gastric pathology including pancreatitis, GERD, gastritis, and peptic ulcer disease. Myocardial infarction should always be ruled out in patients presenting with epigastric pain. Left upper quadrant pain typically suggests a gastric process or a splenic process including infarction, aneurysm, abscess, or a hematologic disease that can cause splenomegaly.

Workup for each of these anatomic regions begins with obtaining basic blood work followed by additional laboratory studies and imaging based on initial findings as well as historical and physical examination findings.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Consult gastroenterology for upper endoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Place a nasogastric tube:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of a gastric process and should have an endoscopy performed. Insertion of a nasogastric tube is not necessary at this time.  
❌ Consult gastroenterology for ERCP:
Incorrect: ERCP is the initial test for patients presenting with acute cholangitis since it can be used for both diagnosis and treatment via biliary decompression. This patient's clinical presentation and history are more consistent with a gastric process.  
❌ Order hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan:
Incorrect: Cholescintigraphy using 99mTc-HIDA scan is indicated in patients with suspected cholecystitis not evident on ultrasound. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a gastric process.  
❌ Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: CT of the abdomen and pelvis would help evaluate for pathology in the liver, biliary tree, pancreas and spleen which could all be causes of upper abdominal pain; however given this patient’s epigastric pain and history of alcohol abuse and NSAID use, upper endoscopy should be ordered to evaluate for gastric pathology.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of severe pain with defecation. She has also noticed bright red blood in her stool. The pain lasts for a few hours after she has a bowel movement. Prior to the onset of the pain and blood in the stool, she had experienced increased straining to pass bowel movements and noticed that her stools were hard. She does not have abdominal pain or fever. She has no significant medical history. Temperature is 99.0°F; pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg. Peri-anal examination reveals a painful lesion that can be seen below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

 Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with painful hematochezia. On physical examination, she has tenderness to palpation and there is a tear in the posterior anal midline, suggesting an anal fissure. Anal fissures are one of the most common causes of anal pain and bleeding. Anal fissures are superficial tears in the anoderm distal to the dentate line and are usually located in the posterior midline. The majority of anal fissures are caused by local trauma such as constipation or diarrhea, vaginal delivery, or anal sex. On physical examination, they appear as superficial lacerations with or without bleeding. At times perianal skin tags may also be present which indicate prior episodes of inflammation or hemorrhoids.

When examining a patient with an anal fissure, the patient should be in the most comfortable position. Anal fissures are very tender to palpation and can be excruciatingly painful for the patient. Therefore, physical manipulation of the anus or rectum should be kept to a minimum, and instrumentation with anoscopy should be avoided if possible.

A thorough history and physical examination is important for developing the differential diagnoses for a patient presenting with hematochezia. One key historical element is the absence or presence of rectal pain. Causes of painless hematochezia include diverticular bleeding, Dieulafoy lesions, angiodysplasia, and colorectal cancer. Causes of painful hematochezia can include anorectal disorders (such as anal fissures, external hemorrhoids, thrombosed internal hemorrhoids, anorectal abscesses, and anal cancer), inflammatory colitis (IBD), and radiation telangiectasia or proctitis. The physical examination helps to distinguish between the various causes.

Option Analysis

✅ Anal fissure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hemorrhoids:
Incorrect: A thrombosed internal hemorrhoid or an external hemorrhoid can cause pain and bleeding similar to an anal fissure. A careful and thorough physical examination will help to distinguish between hemorrhoids and fissures. Anoscopy may be required to diagnose internal hemorrhoids. Thrombosed hemorrhoids will appear as dark, bluish lumps.  
❌ Anal cancer:
Incorrect: Rectal bleeding is the most common initial presentation of anal cancer and some patients may also present with anal pain. On a physical exam, typically a lump or mass can be seen at the anal opening.  
❌ Perianal abscess:
Incorrect: Perianal abscess can also present with rectal bleeding and pain. However, the pain would more likely be constant and not specifically associated with bowel movements. On examination, there would be an area of fluctuance or a patch of erythematous and indurated skin.  
❌ Solitary rectal ulcer syndrome:
Incorrect: Solitary rectal ulcer syndrome is a rare rectal disorder that presents with bleeding, passage of mucus, straining during defecation and a feeling of incomplete bowel evacuation. Pain may also be present. The physical exam findings may vary, but can include the presence of single or multiple ulcerations, polypoid and mass lesions, or just erythema.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the office because of anal itching for the past 4 months. She reports straining every time she goes to the bathroom and feels as if there is a bulging mass in the rectum. She notices bright red blood when wiping. She does not have abdominal pain or rectal pain. She has no medical history and has no family history of colon or rectal cancer. Vital signs are normal. Abdominal exam is unremarkable. On digital rectal examination, there is no visible blood or tenderness to palpation, and there are no palpable masses. Anoscopy is performed with findings of a purple-blue mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with intermittent episodes of painless hematochezia secondary to internal hemorrhoids. The finding of the purple-blue mass on anoscopy confirms the diagnosis. Internal hemorrhoids may not be palpable and are usually painless. They can be a cause of intermittent, limited rectal bleeding.

Lower GI bleeds can be categorized based on the severity of the bleeding as massive, moderate, and occult bleeds. Massive lower GI bleeds usually occur in older patients with multiple medical problems and present as hematochezia (bright red blood per rectum). Patients may be hemodynamically unstable with ongoing bleeding at the time of presentation. Bright red blood would be visible on rectal examination.

Moderate GI bleeds can occur at any age and can present as hematochezia or as melena (black, tar-like stool) if the source is an upper GI bleed. Patients usually are hemodynamically stable. Some disease processes that can cause moderate GI bleeding include neoplastic disease, anorectal diseases, and inflammatory diseases. Patients may not have active bleeding at the time of presentation.

Occult GI bleeds can occur at any age. Patients usually are hemodynamically stable. They may present with symptoms of blood loss or anemia such as lightheadedness, syncope, or dyspnea. Lab evaluation would be notable for microcytic, hypochromic anemia. Occult GI bleeds can be from inflammatory, neoplastic, and congenital causes.

All patients presenting with active, ongoing bleeding should have blood tests obtained to evaluate their hemoglobin and assess the need for transfusion. Blood tests may also help differentiate an active lower GI bleed from an active brisk ongoing upper GI bleed. Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)-to-creatinine ratio can help differentiate between the two. Blood gets absorbed as it travels through the small bowel leading to an increased BUN, and patients may have decreased renal perfusion with an ongoing bleed. This will lead to an elevated creatinine BUN-to-creatinine ratio in patients with an upper GI bleed. In a lower GI bleed, the BUN-to-creatinine ratio would be normal.

An upper GI endoscopy should be performed when an upper GI bleed is suspected. Endoscopy may not be possible if a patient is having active bleeding. However, other diagnostic studies should be obtained to identify the site of bleeding. These may include bedside NG tube lavage, CT angiography, and tagged red cell scan to identify the site of the bleeding. Catheter angiography is both a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that can be done in patients with active, ongoing bleeding.  

Option Analysis

✅ Internal hemorrhoid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Prolapsed internal hemorrhoid:
Incorrect: Prolapsed internal hemorrhoids appear as pink, glistening masses at the anal margin that may be tender.  
❌ Thrombosed internal hemorrhoid:
Incorrect: A thrombosed internal hemorrhoid is typically painful and would appear as a dark, bluish lump visible without the aid of anoscopy.  
❌ Anal fissure:
Incorrect: An anal fissure can be diagnosed without the use of anoscopy. Physical exam would reveal a superficial tear in the anoderm that is tender to palpation.  
❌ Anal fistula:
Incorrect:  The external opening of a fistula would be visualized without the use of anoscopy. The skin might appear indurated or erythematous with pustular drainage appreciated.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of three days of worsening upper abdominal pain and associated vomiting. The patient drinks alcohol daily and has a past medical history of diabetes, hypertension, and gastric ulcers. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 96/66 mmHg, pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. The patient is lying on his left side in the stretcher and appears uncomfortable. Physical examination reveals diffuse tenderness to palpation that is more prominent in the epigastrium and is associated with rebound and guarding. The patient is started on intravenous fluids and his blood pressure improves. He is started on IV pantoprazole,  morphine, and empiric antibiotics. A surgery consultation is called. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain CT-of the abdomen pelvis with IV contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of worsening upper abdominal pain with signs, symptoms, and a physical exam that is suggestive of peritonitis and a possible perforated viscus. Given this patient’s history of gastric ulcers and daily alcohol use, he likely has a perforated gastric ulcer. The patient has been stabilized with IV fluids and analgesia, therefore the next best step in management is to obtain an upright chest radiograph to screen for evidence of free air under the diaphragm, and to call for a surgery consult for evaluation and management of an acute abdomen.

Upper abdominal pain is a symptom that is associated with many conditions, which can range from benign to serious to life-threatening and requiring surgical intervention. One approach to creating a differential diagnosis for upper abdominal pain is to classify the pain by location-right upper quadrant, epigastric, or left upper quadrant. Right upper quadrant pain may be caused by biliary or hepatic processes, while epigastric pain may be caused by pancreatic or gastric pathology. Left upper quadrant pain typically suggests a splenic process.

The first step in management of a patient with upper abdominal pain involves an ABCDE assessment to determine if they are stable or unstable. If the patient is unstable, they require acute management before pursuing a diagnostic workup. Management should involve stabilizing the airway, providing supplemental oxygen, establishing IV access, and continuously monitoring hemodynamics. Unstable patients often have evidence of peritonitis, including diffuse tenderness, rebound tenderness, rigidity, and guarding. These patients should have an upright chest radiograph to screen for free air and a surgical consultation should be called.  

Option Analysis

✅ Obtain upright chest radiograph:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obtain CT-of the abdomen pelvis with IV contrast:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of peritonitis and should have an upright chest radiograph to evaluate for free air while a surgery consult is called. CT of the abdomen and pelvis may lead to delay in surgical care.  
❌ Consult gastroenterology:
Incorrect: This patient's presentation is suggestive of a perforated gastric ulcer with evidence of peritonitis, and gastroenterology consultation would not be appropriate at this time. He should have an upright chest radiograph to look for free air and surgery should be consulted.  
❌ Order an abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of peritonitis and should have an upright chest x-ray obtained to evaluate for free air before other studies are obtained.  
❌ Place a nasogastric tube:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of peritonitis and should have an upright chest radiograph to evaluate for free air, and a surgery consult should be called. Placement of an NG tube in this context could lead to intra-abdominal injury if placed through a perforated viscus.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department for evaluation of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, vomiting, and fever for the past two days. The patient had a laparoscopic cholecystectomy performed one week ago and was discharged on postoperative day 3 without complications. The patient reports her pain as 9/10 on the pain scale. She has a 30-pack-year smoking history, hypertension, and diabetes type 2. She drinks 3 beers daily and reports that her last drink was earlier that morning. Temperature is 38.6°C (102.4°F), blood pressure is 94/64 mmHg, pulse is 134/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Abdominal examination reveals rigidity, guarding, and diffuse severe abdominal tenderness to palpation. The post-operative incisions show no evidence of erythema, tenderness, or drainage. Which of the following findings is most associated with the development of peritonitis and an acute abdomen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of upper abdominal pain 5 days following an uncomplicated laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Her vital signs are notable for SIRS criteria, and her examination reveals evidence of peritonitis, suggesting an acute abdomen (surgical abdomen). The likely cause is a post-surgical complication such as bile leak or abscess formation. Her history of recent abdominal surgery is most associated with the development of peritonitis and an acute abdomen.

Upper abdominal pain is a symptom of many conditions, which can range from benign to serious to life-threatening and require emergent surgical intervention. One approach to creating a differential diagnosis for upper abdominal pain can be to classify the pain by location-right upper quadrant, epigastric, and left upper quadrant.

Historical elements can also help with the differential diagnosis of upper abdominal pain. These include recent abdominal surgeries, as well as risk factors associated with specific conditions (e.g. NSAID use in the context of gastritis or peptic ulcer disease). Importantly, all patients with upper abdominal pain must be assessed for the presence of an acute abdomen which requires emergent surgical evaluation and treatment. Clinical findings of an acute abdomen include diffuse tenderness, rebound pain, rigidity, and guarding.

Option Analysis

✅ Recent abdominal surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ History of smoking:
Incorrect: While smoking may delay wound healing after surgery, it does not increase the risk of postoperative peritonitis.  
❌ Moderate alcohol use:
Incorrect: Alcohol use increases the risk of pancreatitis, alcoholic hepatitis, and cirrhosis, but not peritonitis following surgery.  
❌ History of diabetes type 2:
Incorrect: Diabetes increases the risk of poor wound healing and of having a postoperative cardiovascular event; however, it is not associated with developing peritonitis in the postoperative period.  
❌ Presence of fever:
Incorrect: Fever can indicate an infectious process, but is not a specific finding for peritonitis and acute abdomen.

questions.text:

The patient lives alone and was discovered by a family member today covered in vomitus. The patient drinks alcohol daily and does not have other known medical problems.  Temperature is 39 ºC (102.2 ºF), pulse is 101/min, blood pressure is 100/77 mmHg and respirations are 18/min. The patient has evidence of scleral icterus and appears jaundiced. Physical examination demonstrates a distended abdomen, with evidence of rebound pain and guarding, as well as a positive fluid wave. Abdominal radiograph is within normal limits and initial blood work is shown below. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrates evidence of large intra abdominal ascites and cirrhotic liver morphology. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?

questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of cirrhotic liver disease, ascites, and peritonitis. Together, these findings are consistent with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, a subtype of primary peritonitis. This patient should undergo a diagnostic paracentesis to calculate a SAAG score (serum ascites albumin gradient) which will help confirm the diagnosis.    

Peritonitis refers to the inflammation of the peritoneum. Depending on the etiology, peritonitis can be divided into primary, secondary, and tertiary.    

A CT of the abdomen and pelvis can help to better characterize the type of peritonitis present. Patients with a primary cause will have evidence of intra-abdominal fluid, but a normal GI tract. In contrast patients with secondary peritonitis will have evidence of intra-abdominal fluid, inflammatory changes along GI tract or abscess formation. CT in patients with tertiary peritonitis will demonstrate postoperative inflammatory changes.  

Patients with primary peritonitis should undergo further evaluation via diagnostic paracentesis. Patients with a low SAAG score (<1.1) have peritonitis secondary to a peritoneal cause of the ascites (e.g. not secondary to portal hypertension). Causes include PD catheter dysfunction/infection, peritoneal carcinomatosis, and peritoneal endometriosis. In contrast, patients with a high SAAG score (>1.1) are thought to have peritonitis secondary to portal hypertension, suggesting a diagnosis of SBP.

Option Analysis

✅ Primary peritonitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Secondary peritonitis:
Incorrect: Secondary peritonitis refers to peritonitis caused by peritoneal infections secondary to intra abdominal lesions, such as perforation of hollow viscus, bowel necrosis, nonbacterial peritonitis, or penetrating infectious processes. CT does not show any of these findings, and given his history, this patient most likely has spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
❌ Tertiary peritonitis:
Incorrect: Tertiary peritonitis refers to inflammation of the peritoneum following surgery. This patient's presentation is more consistent with primary peritonitis secondary to ascites and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
❌ Pneumoperitoneum:
Incorrect: Pneumoperitoneum refers to free air found within the peritoneal cavity–this patient's abdominal radiograph does not show evidence of pneumoperitoneum.
❌ Pneumoretroperitoneum:
Incorrect: Pneumoretroperitoneum refers to gas in the retroperitoneal space. This patient’s abdominal radiograph and CT do not show evidence of pneumoretroperitoneum.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent after a suspected toy ingestion. The patient’s parent states their son was playing with magnets, and they saw him swallowing one. They immediately took him to the hospital. The patient is otherwise healthy, is up-to-date on vaccinations, and is meeting developmental milestones. The patient is currently asymptomatic. Vital signs are notable for a temperature of 37 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate of 82, blood pressure of 94/52 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 22/min with SpO<sub>2</sub> of 100% on room air. Physical exam shows a well-appearing child in no distress with clear lung fields bilaterally and a normal abdominal exam. Labs are sent and pending. X-rays of the neck, chest, and abdomen reveal eight magnetic balls connected within the distal stomach. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This four-year-old boy presents to the emergency department in stable condition after witnessing ingestion of magnets. He is asymptomatic with normal vital signs. Imaging reveals eight connected magnets in the distal stomach. Because of multiple magnets, emergency upper endoscopy is required (ideally within two hours) to identify and remove them to prevent development of a pressure-induced stomach injury.

For patients with suspected foreign body ingestion, the initial diagnostic testing includes anteroposterior and lateral radiographs of the neck, chest, and abdomen. When plain radiographs do not reveal a foreign body or abnormalities, further evaluation depends on the characteristics of the patient (i.e., symptomatic, asymptomatic) and the characteristics of the suspected foreign body (e.g., sharp object, large), but most patients should undergo CT imaging.

Emergent endoscopy is recommended when the ingested object is sharp, long (>5 cm), or a superabsorbent polymer and is in the esophagus or stomach, or when the ingested object is a high-powered magnet or multiple magnets. If there are signs of airway compromise, inflammation, or intestinal obstruction, emergency endoscopy should be performed.        

Option Analysis

❌ Observation in the emergency department :
Incorrect: Patients can be observed clinically if only one magnet is present. This patient has ingested eight magnets that are seen in the distal stomach on abdominal X-ray. Emergency endoscopy is required to remove them, as magnets can induce pressure necrosis and perforation. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis with intravenous (IV) contrast :
Incorrect: A CT can be obtained in patients who have equivocal or negative findings on X-ray, when there remains a high clinical suspicion for an ingested foreign body. This patient has a positive X-ray finding.  
✅ Emergent upper endoscopy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Discharge with follow-up in two days :
Incorrect: Patients may be discharged if the object swallowed is seen in the duodenal bulb or distal to it. If the object is radiopaque, X-rays should be performed to track the object’s progress. If it is radiolucent, stools should be checked for passage. The object in this patient is seen in the distal stomach, so discharge is not appropriate.  
❌ Emergent bronchoscopy  :
Incorrect: Patients who have a foreign body aspiration may need emergency bronchoscopy to remove the object. This patient, however, requires an emergent upper endoscopy, because he has evidence of multiple connected magnets in the stomach.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents to a clinic along with her parents for evaluation of abdominal pain for seven months. The pain is periumbilical and does not radiate to the back or chest. The pain occurs three days a month and is described as intense, severe in the morning, associated with nausea, and lasting for an hour. There are no identifiable triggers, and nothing alleviates her pain. She reports no pain between episodes. She has not had bloody stool, weight loss, recurrent fevers, or a skin rash. She has regular bowel movements. She has missed multiple days of school because of her symptoms. Past medical, family and surgical history are non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 115/67 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The physical examination is normal. Complete blood count, liver function, and stool analysis are normal. Abdominal X-ray is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic abdominal pain for more than 6 months that interferes with daily activities with no trigger. Moreover, this patient has a normal physical exam, labs, and imaging – making abdominal migraine the most likely diagnosis.        

Chronic abdominal pain is described as abdominal pain occurring at least 4 times each month for at least 2 months, secondary to organic or functional causes. Functional abdominal pain disorders (FAPDs) usually present with chronic intermittent abdominal pain and include irritable bowel syndrome, functional dyspepsia, abdominal migraine, and functional abdominal pain not otherwise specified. Pathophysiologically, these disorders are characterized by brain-gut dysfunction and are affected by both physical and emotional stressors with no clear organic etiology. Patients with FAPDs have normal physical examination findings and normal labs.         

The Rome IV criteria for abdominal migraines include experiencing each criterion at least twice for at least six months. These include sudden, episodic, intense pain lasting at least one hour with weeks or months of either mild pain or no pain between each episode. Pain must interfere with daily life, and episodes occur in typical patterns for each child. The pain is often associated with symptoms like nausea, vomiting, anorexia, headache, pallor, or photophobia.    

Option Analysis

✅ Abdominal migraine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Celiac disease :
Incorrect: Patients with celiac disease report abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea and steatorrhea related to gluten sensitivity. The abdominal pain in this patient is not related to diet, and the findings are more consistent with abdominal migraine. 
❌ Functional constipation  :
Incorrect: Patients with functional constipation present with less than two defecations per week, stool retention, fecal incontinence with hard bowel movements, and a large fecal mass on rectal exam. This patient has regular bowel movements, and the findings are more consistent with abdominal migraines.  
❌ Primary dysmenorrhea  :
Incorrect: Patients with primary dysmenorrhea have crampy abdominal pain associated with menses that radiates to the lower back, pelvis, or upper thighs. The findings in this patient are more consistent with abdominal migraines. 
❌ Functional dyspepsia :
Incorrect: Patients with functional dyspepsia have postprandial fullness, early satiety, and epigastric pain or burning not associated with defecation. The findings in this patient are more consistent with abdominal migraines.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother for evaluation of recurrent vomiting for one year. The episodes occur every few weeks, lasting 1-2 days, in which the patient vomits multiple times an hour. The episodes are associated with headaches and light sensitivity. There is no fever, vision changes, diarrhea, abdominal pain, or recent travel history. The patient’s appetite and growth have been normal, and there is no history of recent illness or medication use. Family history is notable for migraines in a parent. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient appears well, and the abdominal examination is unremarkable with no tenderness, rebound, or guarding. There is no papilledema. Neurological examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are shown in the table below. Which of the following additional clinical factors is most likely to be present? 

 Laboratory Test     Result    
 Hemoglobin     13.0 g/dL    
 White blood cell count     7,200/µL    
 Serum sodium     137 mEq/L    
 Serum potassium     3.9 mEq/L    
 Serum bicarbonate     22 mEq/L    
 Blood urea nitrogen     16 mg/dL    
 Creatinine     0.7 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent episodes of vomiting lasting 1-2 days, with complete resolution between episodes – a classic presentation of cyclic vomiting syndrome (CVS). The patient lacks signs of increased intracranial pressure, such as vision changes, altered mental status, papilledema, and focal neurological deficits. CVS is frequently associated with migraines and may be triggered by stress, infections, or sleep deprivation. Early morning vomiting is a hallmark feature of CVS and is likely to be identified on further history. Adolescents should be questioned about marijuana use, as it is strongly associated with this condition.       

A focused history is essential in narrowing the differential diagnosis for a pediatric patient presenting with vomiting. Key aspects to explore include the duration, frequency, and characteristics of the vomiting (e.g., bilious, non-bilious, or bloody) and any associated symptoms such as fever, abdominal pain, or changes in bowel habits. It is also important to inquire about recent infections, dietary changes, medication use, and potential exposures to toxins or allergens.       

Physical examination should assess hydration status (e.g., capillary refill, skin turgor, mucous membranes) and evaluate for signs of systemic or localized pathology, such as abdominal tenderness, guarding, or neurologic deficits. Additional clues, such as weight loss, growth delay, or atopic conditions, can help refine the differential diagnosis.   

Option Analysis

❌ Blood in the vomitus:
Incorrect: Repeated retching can lead to minor esophageal tears (Mallory-Weiss tears), resulting in blood-streaked vomitus. However, hematemesis is not a typical feature of cyclic vomiting syndrome.
✅ Early morning vomiting:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Vomiting associated with oral intake:
Incorrect: Cyclic vomiting syndrome is not triggered by oral intake. This condition occurs in stereotypical episodes, regardless of food consumption. Vomiting immediately after eating is more typical of eosinophilic esophagitis or gastroparesis. 
❌ Constipation:
Incorrect: While changes in bowel habits, such as constipation or diarrhea, can occur in some gastrointestinal disorders, they are not typically associated with cyclic vomiting syndrome. 
❌ Dysuria:
Incorrect: Dysuria is not associated with cyclic vomiting syndrome and would point toward a urinary tract infection or genitourinary pathology. It would be expected in a patient with fever, flank pain, or urinary frequency. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with cyclic vomiting syndrome.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents after witnessing a foreign body ingestion. Her parents state she grabbed a fist full of pennies and tried to swallow them. The patient is otherwise healthy, up-to-date on vaccinations, and meeting all developmental milestones. Vital signs are notable for a temperature of 37 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate of 86/min, blood pressure of 90/58 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 22/min with SpO<sub>2</sub> of 100% on room air. Exam reveals a well-appearing child in no apparent distress with clear lung fields and a benign abdominal exam. Labs are sent and pending. X-rays of the neck, chest, and abdomen reveal one, coin shaped object < 1 cm in the distal esophagus. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department asymptomatic and in stable condition after a witnessed foreign body ingestion of a penny. Physical exam is normal. Radiographs reveal a coin in the distal esophagus. Patients with a coin that has recently lodged in the esophagus who can swallow and has no respiratory symptoms can be observed for 12 to 24 hours due to the high rate of spontaneous passage. 

The esophageal coin should be removed promptly if the patient is symptomatic or if the time of ingestion is unknown. If the child is asymptomatic and observed for 24 hours without spontaneous passage of the coin, then, it should be removed by flexible endoscopy. If the child develops any signs or symptoms of obstruction, abdominal pain, vomiting, or fever, then the patient should be reevaluated with radiographs to document that the coin is still in the stomach or duodenal bulb, followed by endoscopic removal. 

Coins that reach the stomach can be managed expectantly. Coins are unlikely to cause complications because they lack sharp edges, are composed of non-toxic metals, and most will pass uneventfully within one to two weeks.   

Option Analysis

❌ Bronchoscopy  :
Incorrect: In this patient, there was a witnessed foreign body ingestion of coins. The patient is asymptomatic, an X-ray reveals one coin in the distal esophagus. A bronchoscopy is an unnecessary, invasive procedure for this patient.  
❌ Upper endoscopy :
Incorrect: In asymptomatic patients with a foreign body ingestion of an object with high-risk features, (i.e., magnetic, large (> 3 cm), sharp) an upper endoscopy is required. In the absence of these features, observation is preferred, as most minimal-risk objects will pass spontaneously. This patient swallowed a penny, which is a low-risk object, and therefore she can be safely observed.  
✅ Observation :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous antibiotics :
Incorrect: In patients who have swallowed an object with high-risk features and there is evidence of upper gastrointestinal perforation on imaging, intravenous (IV) antibiotics should be administered. However, this patient swallowed a low-risk object, has an intact swallowing mechanism, and does not have evidence of respiratory compromise. Therefore, she can be safely observed.  
❌ Proteolytic enzymes  :
Incorrect: Proteolytic enzymes used to be used to break up an impacted food bolus. Today, proteolytic enzymes are not recommended for treatment of food impaction. Their use has been associated with hypernatremia, erosion, esophageal perforation, and aspiration pneumonitis. Additionally, Proteolytic enzymes would not work on coins.

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for evaluation of fatigue and vomiting. The parents report the patient was in his usual state of health when he awoke in the morning. He ate breakfast, went down for a morning nap, and one hour later woke up from his nap vomiting. He had six episodes of non-bloody, nonbilious emesis in the past two hours before his parents brought him to the emergency department. That morning was the first time the patient ate oatmeal. The patient was born full-term and has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 155/min, blood pressure is 85/52 mm Hg, respirations are 32/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the anterior fontanelle is open and flat. The patient is lying in his parents’ arms. He appears alert but fatigued. Mucus membranes are moist. No urticaria, facial or lip swelling is present. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. On abdominal exam there is mild diffuse tenderness but no distension, rebound or guarding and there are normoactive bowel sounds. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Advise parents to avoid oats until age three
Advise parents to reintroduce oats in a smaller amount

questions.solution:
This 8-month-old boy presents for evaluation of multiple episodes of vomiting and fatigue that occurred several hours after eating oatmeal, which is consistent with food protein-induced enterocolitis syndrome (FPIES). Anti-nausea medications and intravenous fluids may be administered acutely to patients with FPIES who continue to have emesis or who appear dehydrated. The long-term management of FPIES is avoidance of the food trigger, in this case oats, until age three, when it can be reintroduced.        

Newborns and infants who present with vomiting should first have an ABCDE assessment. Patients should be given IV hydration if necessary and placed on continuous monitoring. If the patient presents with significant emesis, it may be beneficial to make the patient nothing by mouth (NPO) and insert a nasogastric tube to decompress the stomach. If there is concern for an underlying infection, broad-spectrum antibiotics should be administered. Infants who are unstable or have symptoms of an acute abdomen (e.g., significant abdominal distension and tenderness) should have a surgical consultation for possible laparotomy.  In stable patients, detailed history and physical exams can provide clues to the underlying diagnosis and guide the evaluation and management.   

Option Analysis

✅ Advise parents to avoid oats until age three:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Order oat immunoglobulin E levels:
Incorrect: This patient presents with food protein-induced enterocolitis syndrome (FPIES) secondary to oats. The recommended treatment is to avoid the food trigger until the patient is closer to age three. Oat immunoglobulin E levels would evaluate for an anaphylactic reaction. Emesis without other symptoms is not consistent with an anaphylactic reaction. 
❌ Advise parents to reintroduce oats in a smaller amount:
Incorrect: This patient presents with food protein-induced enterocolitis syndrome (FPIES) secondary to oats. The recommended treatment for this condition is to avoid the food trigger until the patient is closer to age three. Most patients will outgrow the condition and can have the food reintroduced. 
❌ Prescribe histamine (H2) blocker:
Incorrect: H2 blockers can be used to treat gastroesophageal reflux and anaphylaxis. This patient presents with food protein-induced enterocolitis syndrome (FPIES) secondary to oats. The recommended treatment is to avoid the food trigger until the patient is closer to age three.    
❌ Administer intramuscular epinephrine:
Incorrect: Intramuscular epinephrine is used to treat anaphylaxis. This patient has emesis without any other symptoms several hours after ingestion of a new food; this is not consistent with an anaphylactic reaction.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the office because of pain and bulging in his groin. The patient reports that standing exacerbates the pain. The patient is otherwise healthy and has never had surgery. He does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a bulge in the groin that is erythematous and painful to palpation. Scrotal examination is within normal limits. After further evaluation, the patient is diagnosed with a femoral hernia and is scheduled for an endoscopic repair under spinal anesthesia. Which of the following structures is at risk of injury in this patient during the repair?
questions.solution:
This patient with pain and bulging in the groin is found to have a femoral hernia. During femoral hernia repair, sometimes an artery called the aberrant, or accessory, obturator artery can be injured. Typically, the obturator artery branches from the internal iliac artery. In up to 20% of people, however, there can be an additional branch coming from either the inferior epigastric artery or external iliac artery that either replaces the obturator artery or joins it; this phenomenon is called an aberrant or accessory obturator artery. In these patients, the artery runs in close proximity to the femoral ring and courses along the superior pubic rami; so, during hernia repair, it can be injured or stapled.  

When injury occurs, the artery retracts, making it exceedingly difficult to locate and ligate, resulting in uncontrolled bleeding. This artery has been referred to as corona mortis, which means “crown of death,” as injury to it can be fatal.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Ilioinguinal nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal, iliohypogastric, and genitofemoral nerves are at risk of injury during inguinal hernia repair, which can lead to chronic residual neuralgia and postoperative constrictive scar tissue in the surgical area. However, this patient is undergoing repair for a femoral hernia, which poses risk to a different key structure.
❌ Iliohypogastric nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal, iliohypogastric, and genitofemoral nerves are at risk of injury during inguinal hernia repair, which can lead to chronic residual neuralgia and postoperative constrictive scar tissue in the surgical area. However, this patient is undergoing repair for a femoral hernia, which poses risk to a different key structure.
❌ Genitofemoral nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal, iliohypogastric, and genitofemoral nerves are at risk of injury during inguinal hernia repair, which can lead to chronic residual neuralgia and postoperative constrictive scar tissue in the surgical area. However, this patient is undergoing repair for a femoral hernia, which poses risk to a different key structure.
✅ Aberrant obturator artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pudendal nerve:
Incorrect: The pudendal nerve is at risk of injury during sacrospinous ligament fixation or pelvic reconstructive procedures, during which sutures are placed in the arcus tendineus fasciae pelvis. However, this patient is undergoing repair for a femoral hernia, which poses risk to a different key structure.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of a mass on the right side of his groin. The patient first noted the mass after helping his daughter move to a new home. He reports sharp discomfort in the right groin worsens with walking and heavy lifting. Resting supine decreases the severity of the pain. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include atorvastatin and metformin. BMI is 37 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a bulge in the right groin above the inguinal ligament which increases in size when the patient coughs. There is no overlying erythema or warmth. The patient is referred to a surgeon and scheduled for a laparoscopic repair.



Which of the following landmarks will help the surgeon to differentiate a direct versus an indirect inguinal hernia?
questions.solution:
This patient with an examination finding of a bulge in the right groin above the inguinal ligament has most likely developed an inguinal hernia. Inguinal hernias are located above the inguinal ligament. They are classified into direct and indirect hernias. The inferior epigastric vessels are easily visible during laparoscopic hernia repair and are an important landmark to differentiate between the two types of inguinal hernias.

Direct inguinal hernias result from weakness of the transversalis fascia, which makes up the floor of the Hesselbach triangle. Other boundaries include the inferior epigastric vessels laterally, the inguinal ligament inferiorly, and the rectus abdominis muscle medially.
